My Performance Review

March 9th, 2013

Last week I got my performance review. While the feedback was positive overall, no review is complete without citing areas to improve. After I combined the goals of my managers with my own, my plan for the year looked something like this:

Less Twitter

I treat Twitter mostly like an RSS feed. I was usually on it intermittently throughout the day and often found myself reading more than making. Now I rely more on things like Sidebar.io to summarize things. Instapaper helps too.

More Writing

In the spirit of that, Iâ€™ll be doing less tweeting myself. Iâ€™ll still interesting links and chat with friends, but instead of tweeting a bunch of half-baked ideas, Iâ€™d like to make a few of them into thoughtful articles.

Less Dribbble

Since 2010, Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time on dribbble. Being around talented designers had paid off in spades. But when I see things like this or this, I grinds my gears. Keenan Cummings summarizes my viewpoint well. We tend to stay in our own little worlds, high-fiving each other and patting each other on the backs.

Dribbble is still part of my work week, but its focus is more narrow.

2012 @dribbble: The year of the isometric DSLR shot of an iPhone running an app that doesn't work.

— Kyle Neath (@kneath) December 31, 2012

Focus on a Visual Style

When it comes to aesthetics, I tend to explore a little too often. Exploration is good, but I plan on devoting more time a single direction. I started creating a collection of common interface componests in HTML & CSS. If it ever matures, Iâ€™ll put it on GitHub.

More GitHub

Iâ€™d like to contribute more on GitHub, on friendâ€™s projects and my own. Graphical freebies are nice, but theyâ€™re only art. Working code is better.

House Cleaning

Iâ€™ll be going through my Dribbble and Twitter follow lists to find folks treat these sites like more I do: Quality over quantity, reasonable signal vs. noise ratio, mature online etiquette.

Be a Better Employee

Last year I spent a lot of time becoming a better web builder. It worked. Itâ€™s time to focus more on things like project management, team management, presenting, and mentoring within my group here at work.

My Family Is Not My Side Project

Lastly, I donâ€™t want an unhealthy blur between work life and family life. When Iâ€™m home, Iâ€™m home. If my son if awake, Iâ€™m not in front of the computer. If my wife is around, my phone is in my pocket. My family is not my side project. I have hobbies that don't involve an Internet connection.
